importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Eurostar expects to start using the first six double-decker trains in 2031.
The article was published on this date, marking the announcement of the new train order and expansion plans.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline from 2025 to 2031 covers the period during which Eurostar will develop, certify, and begin operating its new double-decker trains.

keyTakeAways: Eurostar has ordered 30 double-decker 'Celestia' trains from Alstom, with an option for 20 more, totaling up to 50 trains.
The expansion will increase Eurostar's fleet by nearly 30%, with new trains expected to begin service in 2031.
Each train is 200 meters long and will allow for around 1,080 seats when two are run together.
The new trains will be 4.33 meters high—just 16cm taller than current E320 models—and will undergo a multi-year certification process across all Eurostar operating countries.
The Temple Mills depot in London will be significantly upgraded with a €80 million investment to support the new trains and accommodate both Eurostar and potential rival operators.
The deal marks the first time double-decker high-speed trains will run through the Channel Tunnel.

Despite the innovation, experts like Pete Waterman warn that most of Britain's railway infrastructure—built 200 years ago—cannot support such trains due to tunnels and overhead lines, making widespread adoption unlikely.
The Office of Rail and Road is reviewing access to Temple Mills depot, as several rival operators (including Evolyn, Virgin, and Gemini Trains with Uber) seek to use it.
Eurostar aims to increase passenger numbers from 19.5 million in 2024 to 30 million, supported by expanded services and new routes to Geneva and Frankfurt.
This move is significant because it represents a major technological and service evolution in cross-Channel rail transport.

namedEntities.name: Eurostar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cross-Channel rail operator providing high-speed services between London and Paris, and other European cities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Eurostar is the central entity in the article, announcing a historic first: introducing double-decker trains through the Channel Tunnel.

namedEntities.name: Alstom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A French multinational transportation company that manufactures rolling stock, including high-speed trains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Alstom is the manufacturer supplying Eurostar’s new double-decker 'Celestia' trains, forming the core of the €2bn train order.

namedEntities.name: Celestia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A model of double-decker high-speed train being developed by Alstom for Eurostar.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 'Celestia' trains are central to Eurostar's plan to modernize its fleet and offer improved comfort and capacity through the Channel Tunnel.

namedEntities.name: Channel Tunnel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A transportation tunnel connecting the UK and France, used by Eurostar for cross-Channel rail services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The tunnel is the critical infrastructure through which the new double-decker trains will operate for the first time.

namedEntities.name: Temple Mills depot
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A London-based depot currently used exclusively by Eurostar to store and maintain its trains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The depot is being upgraded with a €80 million investment to support the new double-decker trains and accommodate potential future rival operators.

namedEntities.name: Gwendoline Cazenave
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief executive of Eurostar, who expressed pride in the new double-decker train initiative.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a key spokesperson for the company, emphasizing the comfort and innovation of the new trains.

namedEntities.name: Pete Waterman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A music producer and train enthusiast who commented on the feasibility of double-decker trains in Britain’s rail network.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His expert opinion highlights infrastructure limitations that may prevent broader adoption of double-deckers across the UK.

namedEntities.name: Evolyn
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Spanish start-up proposing a rival cross-Channel rail service.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Evolyn is one of several potential competitors seeking access to the Temple Mills depot, raising competition concerns.

namedEntities.name: Virgin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A private rail company associated with Sir Richard Branson, which has expressed interest in offering rival cross-Channel services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Virgin is a potential competitor to Eurostar, adding strategic competition to the cross-Channel rail market.

namedEntities.name: Gemini Trains
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A train operator partnering with Uber to launch a new cross-Channel rail service.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This partnership represents another potential rival service challenging Eurostar’s market dominance.

namedEntities.name: Office of Rail and Road
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The UK regulatory body overseeing rail infrastructure and access to key facilities like Temple Mills.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The regulator is reviewing access to Temple Mills and evaluating whether multiple operators can use the depot, influencing future competition and expansion.

namedEntities.name: London St Pancras Highspeed organisation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A government-owned entity managing the Temple Mills depot in London.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The organisation owns the Temple Mills depot and is central to Eurostar’s investment plan for infrastructure expansion.

namedEntities.name: 19.5 million passengers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The number of passengers Eurostar carried last year.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides context for the company’s growth ambitions, targeting a 30% increase in passenger numbers to 30 million.

namedEntities.name: 30 million passengers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The target passenger volume Eurostar aims to reach by increasing services and fleet size.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The target reflects the strategic goal of growing demand and improving service capacity through new trains and routes.

namedEntities.name: 200m
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The length of each new double-decker train.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The length is a key design feature, and when two trains are coupled, creates a 400m service with around 1,080 seats.

namedEntities.name: 4.33 metres
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The height of the new double-decker trains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The height is only 16cm above current models, indicating minimal structural disruption to existing tunnel and infrastructure constraints.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The year when a previous double-decker experiment was introduced on British railways.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It highlights that this is the first time double-deckers are being used through the Channel Tunnel, with only one prior British experiment existing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eurostar has announced a €2bn deal to order up to 50 double-decker 'Celestia' trains from Alstom, marking the first time such trains will operate through the Channel Tunnel. The initiative, which includes a €80m investment in London’s Temple Mills depot, aims to increase passenger numbers from 19.5 million to 30 million and expand service capacity by nearly 30%. The trains will begin service in 2031 and will be 200 meters long, with each train 4.33 meters high—only slightly taller than current models. While Eurostar’s CEO Gwendoline Cazenave highlights the improved comfort and innovation, experts like Pete Waterman warn that Britain's 200-year-old rail infrastructure may not support widespread use due to tunnels and overhead lines. Meanwhile, rival operators such as Evolyn, Virgin, and Gemini Trains with Uber are seeking access to the Temple Mills depot, prompting the Office of Rail and Road to review access rules in the coming weeks.
title: Eurostar orders first double-decker trains
